Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Dimensional and Multi-Physics Analysis of Rainfall-Induced Landslides and Runout

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Landslides are continual natural hazards that can damage infrastructure and cause significant loss of life as occurred in the Oso Landslide (March 22, 2014) in Snohomish County, Washington. Some landslides are rapid and exhibit large runout over few minutes, whereas others are intermittent and move only small distances in a given year. Both of these hazards are usually triggered by precipitation. The main objective of this research project is to develop a three-dimensional (3D) slope stability framework that incorporates unsaturated soil hydraulic properties, effective stresses, and shear strengths to better predict the location, shape, and depth of rainfall-induced landslides, such as the recent Oso Landslide near Seattle and the La Conchita Landslides (1995 and 2005) near Los Angeles. The proposed 3D model will be used to simulate time-dependent variations in saturation from water infiltration, impact of surface vegetation and timbering, and rises in hydrostatic pore-water pressures from runoff that will be used to predict the runout distance based on the calculated factor of safety, slope angle, and pore-water pressures after triggering.

The key product of this research will be a new validated framework for slope stability analyses and landslide risk assessment. This 3D variably-saturated stability analysis framework is important because it accounts for the following factors that are not incorporated in traditional two-dimensional (2D) limit equilibrium slope stability analyses: (1) effective stresses under both saturated and unsaturated conditions, (2) stress-dependent unsaturated and saturated strength envelopes, (3) 3D slide mass geometry, volume, shear forces, and boundary conditions, (4) spatial variation and depth of the unsaturated zone and hydrostatic pore-water pressures across the slide mass, and (5) variation in unsaturated and saturated soil shear strength across the slide mass. Current limitations with 2D analyses affect the calculated limit equilibrium factor of safety and thus the ability to predict the occurrence, shape, volume, and runout distance of the potential slide mass. For example, a 2D analysis does not provide an estimate of the 3D shape and volume, which is key to predicting slide mass volume, pore-water pressures, and runout distance. The results of this project will improve landslide detection, prediction, hazard mapping, land-use planning, and property rights policy decisions. For new subdivisions the geotechnical concerns can be identified and zoning adjusted to manage the risk with the proposed 3D analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop a three-dimensional (3D) limit equilibrium slope stability framework that incorporates unsaturated soil hydraulic properties and shear strength to better predict the location, shape, and depth of massive rainfall-induced landslides. The developed 3D model is able to simulate the months to years of induced variation in saturation from water infiltration, impact of timbering and surface vegetation, associated rise in hydrostatic porewater pressures prior to triggering, and the resulting runout distance based on the calculated factor of safety, slope angle, and pore-water pressures after triggering. We have completed this Goal. A three-dimensional finite element code, based on effective stress principle for unsaturated slope conditions, is established and tested through at least two cases: Mooney Gap at western North Carolina, and Interstate highway 70 in Colorado. The role of the water table variations on landslide initiation or activation have been examined at these two sites. The occurrence of the highest water table level plays an important role in triggering landslides. Through the two sites we showed that three-dimensional topography has significant effect on slope stability; it can affect or over-estimate the factor of safety up to 50% compared to two-dimensional analysis through both hydrologic (pore water pressure or suction) and mechanical (total stress). Thus, in general, accurate prediction/assessment of slope stability requires 3D analysis.

The project has intrinsic scientific merits in terms of advancing the current understanding of slope instability in both natural and engineered environments. The framework developed from this project is be able to simulate time-dependent variations in saturation from water infiltration, impact of surface vegetation and timbering, and rises in hydrostatic pore-water pressures from runoff. The framework is capable of predicting the runout distance based on the calculated factor of safety, slope angle, pore-water pressures after triggering, strength loss, and failure mechanism. Such 3D variably saturated analyses are necessary to account for the following factors that are often overlooked in traditional 2D limit equilibrium slope stability analyses and designs:

  • effective stresses under both saturated and unsaturated conditions,
  • stress-dependent unsaturated and saturated soil shear strength envelopes,
  • 3D slide mass geometry, volume, side shear forces, and boundary conditions,
  • spatial variation and depth of the unsaturated zone and pore-water pressures across the slide mass, and
  • variation in unsaturated and saturated soil shear strength across the slide mass.

Broader impacts of this collaborative project between the Colorado School of Mines (CSM) and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) are reflected in several transformative results. The slope stability framework from this project will improve landslide detection, prediction, hazard mapping, land-use planning, and property rights policy decisions. The following important and transformative results that were generated from this project:

  • investigatory requirements to determine type of failure to expect and possible runout distance to adequately warn property owners of the landslide hazard,
  • shape and type of slide mass for estimating runout based on the investigation,
  • actions that should be taken, e.g., property buyout, toe stabilization, monitoring, installation of a warning system, evacuation during rainy weather, establishment of a Geologic Hazard Area, and
  • recommendations to manage risk to existing developments, e.g., new setback distances, based on understanding the possible slide mass shape, volume, and runout potential.

This collaborative research has provided substantial educational benefits, including research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the CSM and UIUC, and enhanced liaison between academia and industry in natural hazards engineering and science.
